entry.title: Re: Process messages in Controlled Manner in Cloud Integr...
entry.content:
Hi @mastan_vali1 
JMS Sender adapter will process messages immediately. Depending on the size and volume using Datastore + Timer might be a valid  alternative. 

Another option is changing the behavior and instead of the sender pushing the records, SAP Cloud Integration can fetch 500 records per hour using a Service/API/Database.

A third option could be using SAP HANA Cloud (or other DB) as a staging table and then pulling the messages 500 msg/hr.

Best Regards üññüèª,

entry.title: Reclaiming physical disk space on SQL Server (SHRINKFILE)
entry.content:
We would like to reclaim physical disk space after having just been through a data carve-out.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Reclaiming physical disk space on SQL Server (SHRINKF...
entry.content:
SAP Note 1721843 - MSSQL: Post-steps after archiving, deleting or compression

2 - Disk space needs to be released back to the file system

If you carry out archiving/deletion/compression to free space on file system level, you will need to carry out post-processing tasks - otherwise SQL Server data files will keep the space allocated and will not automatically return free space to the file system.

To release space back to the file system,  you can shrink or reorg the database.

Shrinking datafiles or the whole database

Please see:

  • SAP Note 363018
  • DBCC SHRINKDATABASE
  • DBCC SHRINKFILE

for detailed information on shrinking a file or the whole database.

As described in SAP Note 363018 shrinking a datafile or a whole database is an online operation. This means you can run it while the database is open and while other applications like the SAP system use it. Still, you need to be aware of the fact that shrinking is a very I/O intensive operation. It will cause a lot of I/O load which might cause the overall system performance to deteriorate significantly or which might cause blocking locks. For this reason we recommend not to, if possible, run a shrink operation while the SAP system is up and running. If this is not possible you should at least pick a time where the system load is as low as possible. Please note that it is not possible to avoid locks or performance decrease during shrinking operations as shrinking will require to move whole database objects within the datafiles and will therefore require exclusive locks for certain sub-tasks.

Shrinking one or more datafiles might lead to a very high logical fragmentation. Why? Because shrinking starts with the very last page in the file and reorganizes it to a free extent in the first parts of the file. This can lead to physically reverse-ordered pages. The clustered index order will of course be kept by the previous and next pointers, but this is a logical order rather than a physical one. Logical fragmentation after shrinking is therefore a result of the shrink operation as the index will have a reverse order after being reorganized to the beginning of the datafile.

 

SAP Note 363018 - File management for SQL Server

    1. b) Decreasing database files

                       To decrease database files, use the DBCC SHRINKFILE command with a target size for the file. The primary data file (.mdf) cannot be decreased to any target size because it always contains the system tables.

Example (decreasing the file to 1GB):

USE PRD
DBCC SHRINKFILE ('PRD_DATA4',1024)

                       The system tries to decrease the file to the target size. However, the file can be decreased only to the size of the data it contains. If the value for the target size is smaller than the dataset contained in the file, the file is decreased only to the size of the dataset. Data is not moved to other files.

entry.title: Re: [S/4HANA Public Cloud] CDS Extraction to SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hello @popflorin 

The message you‚Äôre seeing is correct, Current Settings (Local Settings) are not transportable by design in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These settings are meant to be editable directly in all systems, including TEST.

If the app is not editable in TEST, that‚Äôs not expected and may point to,

  • The configuration step not being properly scoped in TEST
  • A system issue or restriction in the UI

What you should do

  • Check if the config activity is available and scoped in TEST via Manage Your Solution.
  • If still locked, raise a ticket under
    • SV-BC-CFG for configuration
    • Or BC-SRV-APS-IAM if related to authorization groups

Best regards
Chuma

entry.title: The Next Industrial Revolution: AI Agents At The Heart Of Transformation
entry.content:
The manufacturing sector has always been at the forefront of innovation. From the steam engine to the assembly line, each leap has redefined what‚Äôs possible on the shop floor. Today, we stand at the threshold of another seismic shift‚Äîone powered not just by machines, but by intelligence itself.

The World Economic Forum‚Äôs latest whitepaper, ‚ÄúFrontier Technologies in Industrial Operations: The Rise of Artificial Intelligence Agents,‚Äù paints a compelling picture of this new era.

Why Now? The Case for Frontier Technologies

Industrial operations have long relied on innovations such as robotics and the industrial internet of things (IIoT) to drive productivity and efficiency. But the challenges facing manufacturers today are as complex as they are urgent. Labor shortages, rising costs, volatile supply chains, and the relentless push for sustainability are all converging. Manufacturers must not only optimize cost and efficiency but also adapt to rapid change, ensure resilience, and meet sustainability goals.

Traditional technologies, while powerful, are no longer enough to meet these demands. The answer lies in embracing what the WEF call ‚Äúfrontier technologies." Those that push the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible and unlock new forms of collaborative intelligence between humans and machines.

But why the focus on AI agents, and why now? The answer is simple: AI agents are not just another tool in the digital toolbox. They represent a new paradigm‚Äîone where software and robots can autonomously perceive, decide, and act, freeing up human workers to focus on creativity, strategy, and innovation.

The Rise of AI Agents: Virtual and Embodied

Success requires a leap beyond incremental improvement‚Äîtoward near-autonomous, AI-centric operations that empower people and machines to collaborate seamlessly.

The whitepaper highlights two main types of AI agents driving this transformation:

1. Virtual AI Agents: The Digital Workforce

Virtual AI agents operate within software environments. Think of them as digital colleagues‚Äîalways on, always learning, and capable of making decisions in real time. These agents can act as assistants, advisers, or even fully autonomous controllers, handling everything from production scheduling to predictive maintenance.

For example, a virtual AI agent might monitor a production line, identify bottlenecks, and automatically adjust workflows to optimize throughput. In supply chain management, these agents can analyze vast amounts of data, anticipate disruptions, and recommend alternative sourcing strategies‚Äîoften before a human would even notice a problem.

2. Embodied AI Agents: The New Robotics

Embodied AI agents take things a step further. These are robots equipped with advanced AI, capable of perceiving and interacting with the physical world. Unlike traditional robots, which are limited to repetitive, pre-programmed tasks, embodied AI agents can adapt to changing environments, handle complex assemblies, and even collaborate safely alongside human workers.

Picture a robot that can not only pick and place components but also recognize when a part is defective, adjust its grip, or reroute itself to avoid an obstacle‚Äîno manual intervention required. This is the promise of embodied AI: robotics that are as flexible and intuitive as the people working beside them.

Redefining the Human Role

One of the most exciting‚Äîand perhaps misunderstood‚Äîaspects of this transformation is the role of people.

Karim Lakhani, a professor at Harvard Business School, when asked, ‚ÄúWill AI replace humans?‚Äù, famously replied, ‚ÄúOf course AI won‚Äôt replace humans. But humans with AI will replace humans without AI.‚Äù

Far from replacing humans, AI agents are designed to augment human capabilities. As operations become more autonomous, the role of the worker evolves from hands-on operator to orchestrator and innovator.

Strategic Imperatives: Building the Foundations

Of course, realizing the full potential of AI agents requires more than just deploying new technology. Manufacturers must lay strong organizational and technological foundations:

  • Governance and Change Management: Leadership must champion the transformation, fostering a culture of innovation and trust.
  • Skills and Training: Upskilling and reskilling are essential, with a focus on digital literacy, data analysis, and collaboration.
  • Data and Infrastructure: High-quality, accessible data is the lifeblood of AI. Robust connectivity, cybersecurity, and scalable computing power are non-negotiable.
  • Ecosystem Collaboration: No company can do it alone. Partnerships across the value chain‚Äîsuppliers, technology providers, academia‚Äîare key to accelerating innovation.

Looking Ahead: From Experimentation to Transformation

The journey to AI-driven, near-autonomous operations is just beginning. Early adopters are already seeing tangible benefits, from reduced energy consumption to higher product quality and more resilient supply chains. But the real prize lies ahead: a future where manufacturers can respond to change with agility, drive sustainable growth, and empower their people like never before.

As the white paper concludes, manufacturers who embrace frontier technologies today will be the leaders of tomorrow. The Intelligent Age is here‚Äîare you ready to seize it?

Want to learn more about how AI-powered supply chains meet today‚Äôs needs while preparing for tomorrow? Check out this IDC Analyst Brief: ‚ÄúAI-Powered Business Suite for Supply Chain."

entry.title: Re: Multiple currencies in bank statement
entry.content:
Hello @Rishav4 

SAP S/4HANA Public cloud doesn‚Äôt support posting foreign currency transactions to a local currency (INR) bank account via bank statement. As per SAP Note 3115215, the transaction currency must match the bank account currency.

Possible work around

  • Ask your bank or middleware to convert all transactions to INR before import
  • Use middleware (SAP BTP) to adjust the file
  • Post manually if volume is low

Let me know your statement format if you need help setting this up.

Below are some SAP help useful documentations

2888262 - Currency & not permitted in account & / &

S4 HANA BANK ACCOUNT FOREIGN CURRENCY

With kind regards

Chuma

Since spring 2024 she changed to a smaller consulting company facing to built up the accounting team and the expertise in this area with an approach of a more customer-centric and sustainable consulting to meet the clients on eye-level and bringing real benefit to them.

Topics of interest: Accounting, Finance, Controlling, Governance, Planning, Financial Supply Chain Management

Linda, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

Colleagues from my network suggested the SAP mentor nomination to me. I frequently use to bring up potential topics to my customers as I am hugely interested in bringing a real benefit to them. For me, the role as a mentor can gather the next stage as I can bring the feedback and user experiences from the customers back to SAP. I believe that this combination improves both the products and the consulting services that all of us provide to our clients.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

I strongly recommend staying in touch with your customers. Listen to them and support them in their activities by bringing up creative ideas and solution approaches. Even if you do not get a deal done today, this strengthens your relationship by building mutual trust. Furthermore, I can give the advice to closely work together with junior consultants within your organization. They are highly motivated and thankful to trustworthy mentors. It is not just about the professional and technical expertise. It is also about the soft factors such as communication, organization, taking care, how to push things forward etc. When all of this comes together, you will build up that kind of consultants that we need for the future.

entry.title: Streamlining Access Policies in SAP Cloud Integration(CI/CPI) for Multi-Team Tenant
entry.content:
Access policies within SAP Cloud Integration (CI/CPI) are crucial for managing and organizing resources effectively when multiple teams are working within the same tenant. While there is an excellent blog available which covers the basics on access policies (blog), this blog aims to address the unique challenges that arise when multiple teams need tailored access and wish to avoid clutter caused by unnecessary package creation.

Understanding the Requirements:

If your tenant is bustling with unwanted or empty packages, think names like "PoC Package" or "Test123"‚Äîthen it‚Äôs likely time to optimize your access policies. This blog offers practical solutions for the following requirements:

  1. Dedicated Access for Teams: Ensure that different teams within your organization do not have unauthorized access to each other‚Äôs integration packages.
  2. Targeted Permissions: Assign package access exclusively to the designated teams.
  3. Artifact Creation Control: Prevent teams from creating integration artifacts like iFlows, Value Mappings, and Message Mappings in unassigned packages.
  4. Prevent Package Clutter: Implement a strategy to avoid the creation of unnecessary packages within the tenant.

Example Scenario:

Consider three teams: Team 1, Team 2, and Team 3.

Two users are part of this setup‚ÄîUser 1 belongs to Team 1, and User 2  belongs to Team 2.

Users should have access to packages as depicted below.

For Requirements #1 and #2:

User 1 should have access to Team 1 Package and Housekeeping Package. Here‚Äôs how:

Create a new role within Access Policy

Assign the required packages.

Define a custom role in BTP Cockpit.

Associate this role with a custom Role Collection.

Link this Role Collection to User 1.

 

User 2 is to be granted Team 2 Package access following similar steps.

Create a new role within Access Policy

Assign the required packages.

Define a custom role in BTP Cockpit.

Associate this role with a custom Role Collection.

Link this Role Collection to User 1.

Testing User Access:

User 1: Can edit and incorporate integration artifacts within the Housekeeping Package and Team 1 Package, but not Team 2 Package.

User 2: Can modify and add integration artifacts in Team 2 Package but lacks the same permissions for Team 1 Package.

For more, please refer here

 

Kindly Note:

Both User 1 and User 2 can edit Team 3 Package and create integration artifacts which should not be the case as per our requirement #3

Solution for Requirement #3:

To prevent integration artifact creation in unassigned packages, create a new role in Access Policy that permits artifact creation. Importantly, do NOT assign this role or its collection to User 1 and User 2. Consequently, neither user will be able to create integration artifacts in unauthorized packages.

More Integration Artifacts can be added to this list.

Whenever user tries to access Integration Suite, following is checked in sequence.

1. Whether standard Role Collection is assigned to view the artifact

2. Whether Access Policy is applied on the content accessed

3. Whether User is provided access in Access Policy to edit the content

Now, User 1 and 2 can create integration artifacts only in their assigned packages and they can't create integration artifacts in any other packages.

Handling Unnecessary Package Creation:

User 1 & 2 can still create new packages but because of Solution #3 they cannot create any integration artifacts inside them, thereby minimizing clutter. Now, lets check how to automatically remove these empty packages from the tenant.

Solution Overview:

I have created an iFlow which connects to Integration Content APIs to detect empty packages without integration artifacts and automatically delete them.

iFlow Design :

For Integration Content API Reference, please refer this link

Following steps involved in this iflow:

1. Call GetAccess Token : This will call the Local Integration Process : Get Access Token (1)

2. In Get Access Token, we are calling the token URL from Service key of SAP Process Integration Runtime service which has api plan

3. captureAccessToken - Groovy Script: we parse json response, capture the access token and set it to a access token property

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Step 1: Get the JSON string from the message body
    def body = message.getBody(String)
    
    // Step 2: Parse the JSON input using JsonSlurper
    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()
    def jsonObject = jsonSlurper.parseText(body)
    
    // Step 3: Capture the access_token value
    def accessToken = jsonObject.access_token
    
    // Step 4: Set this value to the property accessToken
    message.setProperty("accessToken", accessToken)
    
    // Return the modified message
    return message
}

4. Set Authorization Header - Content Modifier: We set Accept and Authorization Headers

5. Request Reply : To call the API and get the list of all the Integration Packages in the tenant

 

6. JSON to XML Converter : This is used to convert JSON to XML structure

7. General Splitter - Since the response contains all the packages in a single response, we can split it based on the XPATH //results

8. Call - Empty Package Check : To call the Local Integration Process- Empty Package Check(2)

9. Set Package id - Content Modifier : to set the packageid property

 

10. Request - Reply : To check if Integration Design Time Artifacts are available inside each package

11. Call - Delete Empty Packages: To call the Local Integration Process Delete Empty Packages(3)

12. deleteEmptyPackages - Groovy Script: To parse the response and check if the response is empty (which indicates Package is empty), set the property deletePackage as true. If not, set it as false

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Retrieve the body of the message
    String body = message.getBody(String)
    
    // Parse the JSON input using JsonSlurper
    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()
    def jsonObject = jsonSlurper.parseText(body)
    
    // Check if the JSON structure matches {"d":{"results":[]}}
    def isEmptyResults = jsonObject?.d?.results?.isEmpty()
    
    // Set the property deletePackage based on the check
    if (isEmptyResults) {
        message.setProperty("deletePackage", true)
    } else {
        message.setProperty("deletePackage", false)
    }

    // Return the modified message
    return message
}

13. Router: To route the messages based on the deletePackage value

14. Request - Reply: To call the API for Package deletion

15. Exception Handling: If the package is locked then the message fails. Hence, setting a custom header with likely cause. This can be extended as per your requirement.

Testing:

Empty packages are created by User 1 & 2 because they can't create Integration Artifacts inside it because of Solution#3

Run the flow

All the empty packages are deleted now

Now, if one of the empty package is locked under a user then the flow will fail and likely cause is set as custom header which is set in exception subprocess 

Conclusion:

Efficient management of access policies within SAP Cloud Integration is essential for organizations utilizing shared environments among multiple teams. By implementing tailored access controls, you can ensure that each team has exclusive access to their designated packages. This approach optimizes collaborative workflows by preventing unauthorized modifications to integration packages.
Furthermore,  restriction on the creation of integration artifacts in unassigned packages helps in maintaining a structured and clutter-free tenant. Introducing automated solutions, like the iFlow for detecting and deleting empty packages, further streamlines operations by eliminating unnecessary resource allocation.

I invite you to share your thoughts in the comments below. Whether you have questions about Access Policies, experiences to share, or suggestions for improvement, your feedback is invaluable. It helps others who are navigating similar journeys and contributes to a community of shared knowledge. I look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: Re: ABSENCE QUOTA CARRY OVER
entry.content:
I think that is because you are using the UPDTQA operation, which does not generate the record for you. If you want the system to generate the record, you should set up a new quota generation rule with the base entitlement set to time type ZQEU.

Alternatively, you can build a program to generate the IT2006 at the beginning of each year.

entry.title: Re: How to use Migrate Allocation Cycles new feature?
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,


The new feature "Migrate Allocation Cycles" is to migrate cycles created in the old app "Overhead Allocation Cycles - Cost Centers - Actual". The current application for Universal Allocation is "Manage Allocation" and you can start/continue to use that one if you don't have cycles from old app in your system.

Universal Allocation

Manage Allocations (New Version)


Best Regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @Nektarios_Vasileiou33 and @BlazZabukovec .

Picture 1: SAP Analytics Cloud demo story example - Dashboard design by Daniel Davis

Motivation

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support ‚Äì going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering (THIS BLOG POST)

  2. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?

  3. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world

  4. Planning & Analysis in the context of SAP BDC

  5. Move BPC and BW-IP into SAP BDC

  6. Real-time steering with LIVE planning

  7. PaPM use cases

  8. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real time business steering

  9. Business steering powered by AI agents

  10. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting

  11. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

CHALLENGES

The current global market situation is characterised by heightened volatility and uncertainty, driven by factors such as geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures and rapid technological advancements. In this dynamic environment businesses face significant challenges like supply chain disruptions, rising and uncontrolled operational costs and the need for digital transformation to remain competitive.

Obviously, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to every challenge, but adopting a data-driven decision-making process provides significant advantages that can help organizations navigate complexities and respond more effectively to market dynamics. By relying on data to drive decisions, businesses can achieve greater accuracy and insight, which helps in identifying trends, understanding customer behaviours, and optimising operations. This approach enables companies to be more agile and responsive to changing conditions.

Every leader today feels the weight of growing complexity. CFOs balancing growth and profitability. CHROs managing talent in an evolving workforce. CIOs modernising IT while keeping innovation alive.

Picture 2: Challenges by CXO persona

But the true challenge lies in how these functions are increasingly interconnected. When one part of the business is disrupted, whether it‚Äôs a supply chain issue or a talent gap, the ripple effects are felt everywhere. To succeed, businesses need more than solutions for individual challenges, businesses need a way to align every function and unlock collective power.

Like Aristotle (apparently) once said: ‚ÄúTHE WHOLE IS GREATER THAN THE SUM OF ITS PARTS‚Äù

Today‚Äôs complexity demands more than incremental fixes and silo apps/solutions. If we want to have benefits from AI and systems of agents collaborating across all functions, we need to have a solid foundation, where we can seamlessly combine applications, data, insights and AI into one ecosystem.

Just picture this example around Financial Planning (incl. forecasting & simulation), where we can develop a comprehensive financial snapshot while automating workflow tasks through agentic AI.

Picture 3: Forecasting & Simulation use case evolution

This is where we bring together all relevant data, like revenues, expenses, also across different scenarios, like actuals, plan & forecast. We also integrate all relevant external data, like different macro-economic KPIs, external market research data., etc. Based on identified key drivers/influencers of our business, we are going to define and perform different planning/forecasting scenarios. In the next step we are going to simulate and analyse impact of external drivers like inflation rate on our performance and identify the areas that will be impacted. Specialised analytics agent can propose potential mitigation strategies, like targeted promotions to drive customer demand, that can be further assessed & analysed. Based on this information we can decide for a certain course of actions that can be triggered by system of agents.

Picture 4: Risk analysis & mitigation strategies delivered by agentic AI

We can say with great confidence that our customers are not working in the area of visualising their data and that‚Äôs why SAP is also not in the business of visualising our customer‚Äôs data (even though we can do this is in a great way), but we are in a business of enabling the ‚ÄúInsights to Action‚Äù framework which is exactly what I have illustrated in the use case around financial planning powered by agentic AI.

Organizations striving to make data-driven decisions and a proper, also AI powered jump from insights to action, encounter several significant challenges. One major obstacle is seamlessly integrating data across various systems to extract valuable business insights. Additionally, ensuring data quality and integrity is crucial to maintaining trust in the decision-making process. Furthermore, building a comprehensive data foundation is essential for supporting the deployment of AI-based applications. Addressing these challenges requires robust data management strategies and innovative solutions to harness the full potential of data for valuable decision-making.

SAP's STRATEGY

To tackle these challenges, SAP developed the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to provide cloud services that empower organizations in navigating the complexities of data management and business steering process. SAP BDC serves as a unified platform, providing the necessary agility for effective business steering. SAP BDC offers a semantically rich, unified data environment that enhances operational efficiency and strategic decision-making capabilities. By centralising key business data from SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer, SAP BDC unlocks insights, advanced analytics, and AI capabilities, empowering businesses to drive intelligent growth and innovation.

Picture 5: SAP Business Suite

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a fully managed Software as a Service (SaaS) solution that unifies and governs all SAP data while seamlessly connecting with third-party data. The solution combines the capabilities of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse, along with managed SAP Databricks. SAP BDC includes curated business-ready data products from SAP line of business applications leveraged by business-ready Intelligent Applications providing line-of-business leaders the context needed to make impactful decisions.

Picture 6: High level overview of SAP BDC services

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud:

SAP Datasphere: As the foundational element of SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere provides a streamlined environment for data integration, warehousing, and governance. It features flexible integrated data tiering‚Äîcomprising object, disk-based, and in-memory storage‚Äîensuring a cost-effective persistence layer. Additionally, it offers sophisticated tools for analytical data modeling, transformation, and integration, enabling organizations to extract valuable insights and foster business innovation. Users can also utilize the framework to develop their own data products.

SAP Analytics Cloud: This component delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience.

SAP Databricks: Through SAP's partnership with Databricks, data science capabilities are significantly enhanced. This collaboration facilitates advanced analytics and data science operations on both SAP and non-SAP data. Key features include ML Flows for machine learning operations, Mosaic AI for model training and serving, and Notebooks equipped with coding assistants and visualizations. The serverless Spark offerings aim to simplify big data processing, while replication-free access to SAP data products and integration with the Unity Catalogue further enrich the experience.

Intelligent Applications and Data Products: SAP Business Data Cloud emphasizes Intelligent Applications and SAP-managed Data Products. These ready-to-use, standardized business data objects and applications are managed by SAP, reducing the effort needed to build and operate analytical and data science applications. They promote data consistency and reusability, serving as modular, reusable assets for analytical models or AI/ML and planning workflows.

Unified Semantic Layer: Central to SAP Business Data Cloud is the unified semantic model, which standardizes data definitions across SAP and non-SAP systems. It offers simplified zero-copy data access via a standardized delta-share interface, supporting cross-domain analytics and AI applications. Additionally, it features a centralized cross-application catalog for data products and Intelligent Applications.

SAP BW: is integrated into SAP BDC, allowing SAP BW objects to be onboarded as data products. The SAP BW data products can be integrated in SAP Databricks to enable advanced analytics and data science use cases.

BUSINESS VALUE

SAP BDC delivers significant business value in the context of business steering, particularly within planning and analytics use cases. 

Enhanced Decision-Making: SAP BDC revolutionises decision-making by providing real-time access to integrated data. This SAP Analytics Cloud capability ensures that business leaders receive accurate and immediate insights, empowering them to make informed and strategic decisions. With this enhanced decision-making capacity, organizations can effectively anticipate market trends, adjust their strategies in response to evolving conditions, and maintain a competitive edge in their respective industries.

Comprehensive Data Integration: At the heart of SAP BDC is its ability to seamlessly integrate data from multiple sources, both SAP and non-SAP systems. This integration creates a unified view of the organisation's data landscape, supporting precise planning and predictive forecasting. By breaking down data silos and ensuring a holistic perspective, SAP BDC enables businesses to gain comprehensive insights into their operations and make well-rounded decisions. The data holistic perspective is fundamental for organizations to unleash AI across the entire data ecosystem.

Scalable Analytics and Planning Capabilities: One of the standout features of SAP BDC is its scalable analytics and planning capabilities. It allows businesses to conduct extensive analyses and simulations, uncovering valuable insights that aid in tailoring forecasts to specific scenarios. Whether it's understanding customer behavior or predicting market shifts, SAP Analytics Cloud robust analytics and planning capabilities in combination with SAP Databricks empower organizations to make data-driven predictions with unmatched precision and confidence.

Improved Efficiency and Agility: SAP BDC streamlines data integration and analytics processes, significantly enhancing efficiency and agility within organizations. By automating these crucial processes, leveraging data management features in SAP Datasphere, analytics in SAP Analytics Cloud and AI/ML workflows in SAP Databricks, it cuts down the time and effort needed for data preparation and analysis (replication free access of data and zero-copy). This efficiency allows teams to redirect their focus from operational concerns to strategic steering, driving more meaningful business results in less time.

Facilitated Innovation: Leveraging cutting-edge technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, SAP BDC promotes innovation within organizations. Its cloud-based infrastructure ensures that businesses have access to the latest advancements, encouraging the exploration of new and innovative business models. This focus on facilitated innovation helps companies remain at the forefront of industry trends and continuously evolve their offerings.

Consistency in Data Governance: Ensuring data integrity and consistency is a critical component of SAP BDC's value proposition. The platform offers comprehensive data governance and quality management, providing reliable data integrity across planning and analytics activities. With consistent data definitions and governance, businesses can achieve accurate reporting and foster alignment across various departments, leading to cohesive planning strategies.

Seamless Collaboration: SAP BDC enhances collaboration by centralising data accessibility and sharing. Data Cataloguing, Data Sharing and Collaboration capabilities foster improved teamwork among departments and enables synchronised planning efforts and a guided steering process. With shared insights and aligned goals, teams can work together more effectively, driving unified strategies and achieving common objectives that benefit the entire organisation.

Strategic Resource Allocation: Through its predictive analytics and planning capabilities SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Databricks, SAP BDC enables organizations to allocate resources more strategically. By delivering actionable insights, businesses can optimize operations, improve resource allocation, and enhance overall performance. This strategic approach ensures that resources are used efficiently to achieve maximum impact, driving profound business success.

Future-Proofing Autonomous Business Steering: By harnessing SAP AI agents within the trusted SAP BDC data foundation, the planning and business steering process is transformed from a static, periodic exercise into a dynamic, proactive function. These AI-driven insights empower companies to swiftly assess the potential impacts of various strategic options and make decisive actions. This approach allows businesses to anticipate market changes and respond efficiently, making strategic adjustments with confidence and precision.

CONCLUSION

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) stands as a vital tool for organisations striving to enhance their decision-making capabilities, align strategic objectives, and navigate the complexities of modern business landscapes. In the era of AI, organizations require scalable and efficient data architectures to manage growing volumes of data and extract actionable insights leveraging advanced analytics, planning and machine learning capabilities. As we embark on this informative blog series, we invite you to stay tuned for our upcoming posts, where we will delve deeper into the AI, Planning & Analytics functionalities associated with SAP BDC and business steering use cases. Gain insights into how this powerful platform can drive your business forward, optimise operations, and help you achieve your strategic goals with confidence. Join us in exploring the transformative potential of SAP BDC and discover how it can be the catalyst for your organisation's growth and success.

CALL TO ACTION

To deepen your understanding of SAP Business Data Cloud, we invite you to explore the following links:

SAP Business Data Cloud Help

https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud?locale=en-US

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/leveraging-sap-analytics-cloud-functionality-for-enterprise-planning/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

Positioning SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/positioning-sap-business-data-cloud-1

entry.title: How to schedule integrations after SuccessFactors Employee central data centers move to UTC time zon
entry.content:
Hello Experts, 

Considering the fact that all SuccessFactors data centers have moved to the UTC time zone, how can one schedule Cloud platform integrations to correctly pick up records that have become effective on a certain day?

Details - Let's assume my SF EC data center is in Tokyo. And let's also assume that I run my HRIS synch at 1 AM UTC, which is 10 AM JST. The future dated Job information records will become current dated only after the HRIS sync (I could be wrong here). So, in this case, only if I run the integration after 1:15 UTC (10:15 AM JST) will the integration pick up all the records that have become effective on that day. If I run the integration at around 4 AM, the UTC time is still 7 PM the previous day and it won't pick up the records that have become effective on the current day. 

Is there a solution to this? How can I manage to pick up all the records that have become effective on a certain day (along with changes since the last time the integration ran), when I run the integration early in the morning, when it's still the previous day in UTC time zone?

I am currently using Compound Employee SOAP call with last modified on and fromDate/toDate filters. 

Thanks

Kriba

entry.title: Re: Former AppGyver application fails to build on SAP Build Apps - 99% build, fails on @sba-runtime
entry.content:
Due to not being able to recover the content of my application I resorted to use AI to help me extract all the content from my application to help reduce the burden if needing to move to another platform. Ideally if the 'Web application' deployment worked it would have made my life a bit easier.

In case anyone wants to follow my footsteps, you can consider using this script.

This script automates crawling and downloading content from SAP Build Pages. Paste it into your browser‚Äôs DevTools console while on the grid page. You can customize the starting index and wait times at the top. It handles navigation, waits for content to load, and downloads each page as HTML.

/**
 * AutoCrawler for SAP Build Pages
 * --------------------------------
 * Automates:
 * 1. Clicking each page link on the "show all pages" in grid view (without page preview)
 * 2. Waiting for content to load
 * 3. Downloading the HTML
 * 4. Returning to the grid
 * 
 * CONFIGURATION:  
 *   ‚Ä¢ GRID_PAGE_URL            ‚Äì URL of the grid view  
 *   ‚Ä¢ GRID_ITEM_SELECTOR       ‚Äì CSS selector for grid items  
 *   ‚Ä¢ CONTENT_CONTAINER_SELECTOR ‚Äì CSS selector for the content wrapper  
 *   ‚Ä¢ PAGE_TITLE_SELECTOR      ‚Äì CSS selector for page titles  
 *   ‚Ä¢ TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_CONTENT_LOAD ‚Äì ms to wait on content pages  
 *   ‚Ä¢ TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_GRID_LOAD    ‚Äì ms to wait on grid page  
 *   ‚Ä¢ LOOP_INTERVAL            ‚Äì ms between URL/state checks  
 *   ‚Ä¢ START_INDEX              ‚Äì zero-based index to resume from  
 * 
 * USAGE:
 * 1. Open your grid URL in the browser.
 * 2. Paste this script into the console.
 * 3. It will log each step and download each page‚Äôs HTML.
 */

const GRID_PAGE_URL                = 'https://agcommunity.design-time.eu10.apps.build.cloud.sap/builder/applications/47416/pages';
//                                                                                           This number will change ^^^^^
const GRID_ITEM_SELECTOR           = '.top_bar__pages__page_link';
const CONTENT_CONTAINER_SELECTOR   = '.c3__page-sides';
const PAGE_TITLE_SELECTOR          = '.fd-select__text-content';

const TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_CONTENT_LOAD = 20000; // ms
const TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_GRID_LOAD    = 5000;  // ms
const LOOP_INTERVAL                 = 1000;  // ms
const START_INDEX                   = 0;     // resume here

// Internal state
let index        = START_INDEX;
let items        = [];
const processed  = new Set();
let lastPageId   = null;
let isBusy       = false;

// Simple prefixed logger
const log = (...args) => console.log('[AutoCrawler]', ...args);

// Returns the numeric ID if on a content page, else null
const isContentPage = () => {
  const m = location.href.match(/\/pages\/(\d+)$/);
  return m ? m[1] : null;
};

// Grabs the container whose HTML we‚Äôll download
const getCaptureTarget = () =>
  document.querySelector(CONTENT_CONTAINER_SELECTOR) || document.body;

// Download the current page‚Äôs HTML once, skipping duplicates
const captureAndDownload = () => {
  const target = getCaptureTarget();
  const titleEl = document.querySelector(PAGE_TITLE_SELECTOR);
  const title   = titleEl
    ? titleEl.innerText.trim()
    : `page-${Date.now()}`;

  if (processed.has(title)) {
    log(`‚ö†Ô∏è Already processed "${title}". Skipping.`);
    return;
  }

  processed.add(title);
  const blob = new Blob([target.outerHTML], { type: 'text/html' });
  const a    = document.createElement('a');
  a.href     = URL.createObjectURL(blob);
  a.download = `${title}-content.html`;
  document.body.appendChild(a);
  a.click();
  document.body.removeChild(a);
  log(`‚úÖ Downloaded "${title}".`);
};

// Clicks the ‚ÄúShow all pages‚Äù menu item to return to the grid
const goToGridViaMenu = () => {
  if (location.href === GRID_PAGE_URL) {
    log('üü© Already on grid. No need to click menu.');
    return;
  }

  log('üîÅ Clicking "Show all pages" to return to grid...');
  const link = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('a.fd-menu__link'))
    .find(el => el.getAttribute('aria-label') === 'Show all pages' && el.offsetParent);

  if (link) {
    link.click();
    log('üü¢ Menu click fired.');
  } else {
    log('‚ùå Menu link not found. Will retry on next loop.');
  }
};

// Finds and clicks the next grid item
const clickNextGridItem = () => {
  items = document.querySelectorAll(GRID_ITEM_SELECTOR);
  if (items.length === 0) {
    log('‚ö†Ô∏è No grid items found.');
    return;
  }

  if (index < items.length) {
    log(`üñ±Ô∏è Clicking item ${index + 1} / ${items.length}`);
    items[index].click();
  } else {
    log('‚úÖ All items finished.');
  }
};

// Main loop: checks URL, triggers actions, and re-schedules itself
const loop = () => {
  if (isBusy) {
    log('‚è≥ Busy, waiting for current action to complete...');
    return setTimeout(loop, LOOP_INTERVAL);
  }

  const contentId = isContentPage();

  if (contentId && contentId !== lastPageId) {
    // We‚Äôve landed on a new content page
    isBusy     = true;
    lastPageId = contentId;
    log(`üü¶ Content page #${contentId} detected.`);
    log(`‚è≥ Waiting ${(TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_CONTENT_LOAD/1000)}s for content to load...`);
    setTimeout(() => {
      log('üì• Initiating download...');
      captureAndDownload();
      index++;
      log(`‚è≥ Waiting ${(TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_GRID_LOAD/1000)}s before returning...`);
      setTimeout(() => {
        goToGridViaMenu();
        isBusy = false;
      }, TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_GRID_LOAD);
    }, TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_CONTENT_LOAD);

  } else if (location.href === GRID_PAGE_URL) {
    // We‚Äôre back on the grid
    isBusy = true;
    log('üü© Grid page detected.');
    log(`‚è≥ Waiting ${(TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_GRID_LOAD/1000)}s for grid to render...`);
    setTimeout(() => {
      clickNextGridItem();
      isBusy = false;
    }, TIME_TO_WAIT_FOR_GRID_LOAD);

  } else {
    // Neither grid nor content pages
    log(`‚ùì Unknown URL: ${location.href}`);
  }

  // Always check again after LOOP_INTERVAL
  setTimeout(loop, LOOP_INTERVAL);
};

// Kick it off
log('üöÄ AutoCrawler started. Resume index:', START_INDEX);
loop();

ËßÜÂõæÊµèËßàÂô®Â¢ûÂº∫

  1. Â¶ÇÊûúÂÖ¨ÂÖ±ÈÉ®Èó®ÁÆ°ÁêÜ (PSM) Âú®Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠Â∑≤ÊøÄÊ¥ªÔºåÂàôÊó†Ê≥ïÂêØÁî®Âü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁªìÁÆóÂà∞Âú®Âª∫Â∑•Á®ãÂú∫ÊôØ„ÄÇ
  2. ‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÂà∞Âú®Âª∫Â∑•Á®ãÁöÑÈáëÈ¢ùÁªìÁÆó„ÄÇ
  3. ‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÂà∞ÂÖ∂‰ªñÊàêÊú¨ÂØπË±°ÁöÑÂàùÊ≠•ÁªìÁÆó (ÁªìÁÆóÁ±ªÂûãPRE/VOR)„ÄÇ
  4. ‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÂü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÈó¥Êé•Ë¥πÁî®ËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇ
  5. ‰∏çÊîØÊåÅË°åÈ°πÁõÆÈáçÊñ∞ËøáË¥¶„ÄÇ
  6. ‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÈÄöËøáË¥¢Âä°‰∏öÂä°‰∫§ÊòìÊé•Âè£ (ABTI ‚Äì Accounting Business Transaction Interface) ËøáË¥¶„ÄÇ

ÊúâÂÖ≥Êñ∞ÂäüËÉΩÈôêÂà∂ÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåËØ∑ÂèÇÈòÖ SAP Note 3615670 

 

‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÈáëÈ¢ùÁªìÁÆó

‰ª•Á≥ªÁªüÊµãËØïÁªìÊûú‰∏∫‰æãÔºåÂü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁªìÁÆóÁöÑÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÂíåÂú®Âª∫Â∑•Á®ãËôΩÁÑ∂ÂêåÊ†∑ÈÉΩÊòØÂ∫îÁî®ÁªìÁÆóÂèÇÊï∞Êñá‰ª∂YPSAUCÔºå‰ΩÜÂÖ∂ÁõÆÂâç‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÈáëÈ¢ùÁªìÁÆó„ÄÇ

Áõ¥Êé•Ë°®Áé∞ÊòØÂç≥‰ΩøÂú®ÁªìÁÆóÂèÇÊï∞Êñá‰ª∂YPSAUC‰∏≠ÂãæÈÄâ‰∫ÜÂÖÅËÆ∏‚ÄúÈáëÈ¢ùÁªìÁÆó‚ÄùÔºåÂú®ÂÆûÈôÖÁª¥Êä§ÁªìÁÆóËßÑÂàôÊó∂‰πü‰∏çÊòæÁ§∫ÈáëÈ¢ùÂ≠óÊÆµÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Êó†Ê≥ïÁºñËæëÁª¥Êä§ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÁªìÁÆóÈáëÈ¢ù„ÄÇ

 

‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÂàùÊ≠•ÁªìÁÆó

Âè¶Â§ñÔºåËôΩÁÑ∂ÊÇ®Âú®Áª¥Êä§ÊäïËµÑÁªìÁÆóËßÑÂàôÊó∂ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄâÊã©ÁªìÁÆóÁ±ªÂûã‰∏∫ÂàùÊ≠•ÁªìÁÆóÔºàPREÔºâÔºå‰ΩÜÊÇ®Âú®ÂÆûÈôÖËøêË°åÈ°πÁõÆÁªìÁÆóÊó∂ËøòÊòØ‰ºöÊòæÁ§∫Êä•Èîô‰ø°ÊÅØ‚Äú‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÁ±ªÂûã‰∏∫PREÁöÑÂàÜÈÖçËßÑÂàô‚Äù„ÄÇ

ËØ∑Ë∞®ÊÖéËØÑ‰º∞‰∏äËø∞ÈôêÂà∂ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊÇ®ÂèëÁé∞‰∏äËø∞ÈôêÂà∂‰ºöÂΩ±ÂìçÊÇ®ÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ãÔºåËøòËØ∑ÁªßÁª≠‰ΩøÁî®‰º†ÁªüÁöÑÂü∫‰∫éÊúüÈó¥ÁªìÁÆóÁöÑÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÁÆ°ÁêÜÊÇ®ÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÇ

entry.content:
„ÄêËÆ°ÂàíÂÆâÊéí„Äë
‰∏âÁ≥ªÁªüÂçáÁ∫ßÂèäÁª¥Êä§ËÆ°Âàí 
‰∏§Á≥ªÁªüÂçáÁ∫ßÂèäÁª¥Êä§ËÆ°Âàí

„ÄêÊñ∞ÂäüËÉΩ„Äë
1. ‚ÄúËøáË¥¶ËµÑ‰∫ßË¥≠ÁΩÆ-ÂíåÊï∞ÈáèË∞ÉÊï¥‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ÊîØÊåÅÊÄªË¥≠ÁΩÆ‰ª∑
Ë¶ÅÈÄöËøáÈááË¥≠ËøáË¥¶ËµÑ‰∫ßË¥≠ÁΩÆÔºåËÄåÊó†ÈúÄÂèÇËÄÉÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢Âçï‰ª•Âèä‰∏éÂ∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æ‰ºöËÆ°ÈõÜÊàêÔºåËÄåÊòØÈíàÂØπÊ∏ÖÁÆóÁßëÁõÆËøáË¥¶ÔºåËØ∑‰ΩøÁî®ËøáË¥¶ËµÑ‰∫ßË¥≠ÁΩÆ - ÂíåÊï∞ÈáèË∞ÉÊï¥Â∫îÁî® (F6488)„ÄÇ
‰πãÂâçÔºåÂè™ËÉΩ‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§Â∫îÁî®ËøáË¥¶ÂáÄË¥≠ÁΩÆ, Ë¥≠ÁΩÆÔºàÂáÄÈ¢ùÔºâÔºöËøôÊòØÊ†áÂáÜÈÄâÈ°π„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§ÈÄâÈ°πÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÊåáÂÆöÔºàÂáÄÔºâË¥≠ÁΩÆÊàêÊú¨„ÄÇ
‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåÁé∞Âú®ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúË¶ÅËøáË¥¶Èô§Ë¥≠ÁΩÆÂíåÁîü‰∫ßÊàêÊú¨ (APC) Â§ñÂÖ∑ÊúâÂÄºË∞ÉÊï¥ÁöÑËµÑ‰∫ßÁöÑËµÑ‰∫ßË¥≠ÁΩÆÔºåÂàôÂèØ‰ª•ËøõË°åÊÄªÂÄºËøáË¥¶„ÄÇ‰∏∫Ê≠§Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®Êñ∞‰∏öÂä°‰∫§ÊòìÁ±ªÂûãË¥≠ÁΩÆÔºàÊÄªÈ¢ùÔºâ„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂêéÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ËæìÂÖ• APC ÂíåÁõ∏ÂÖ≥‰ª∑ÂÄºË∞ÉÊï¥Ôºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÊôÆÈÄöÊàñËÆ°ÂàíÂ§ñÊäòÊóß„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§ÈÄâÈ°πÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÊåáÂÆö‰ΩøÁî®Âπ¥ÈôêÂºÄÂßãÊó∂ÁöÑÂéüÂßãË¥≠ÁΩÆÂíåÁîü‰∫ßÊàêÊú¨Ôºå‰ª•ÂèäÂú®ÈááË¥≠Ââç‰∫ßÁîüÁöÑËµÑ‰∫ßÊäòÊóß„ÄÇ

2. ËµÑ‰∫ßËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÁâπÊÆäÊúüÈó¥(Ë∞ÉÊï¥ÊúüÈó¥)
ÂØπ‰∫éËµÑ‰∫ß‰ºöËÆ°Ôºå‰ª•‰∏ãÂÜÖÂÆπÈÄÇÁî®Ôºö‰πãÂâçÔºåÂú®Áî®‰∫éËµÑ‰∫ßËøáË¥¶ÁöÑ SAP Fiori Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÊó†Ê≥ïÂú®ÁâπÊÆäÊúüÈó¥ËøáË¥¶„ÄÇÁé∞Âú®ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊâßË°åÊ≠§Êìç‰Ωú„ÄÇË¥¢Âä°‰ºöËÆ°ÁöÑÊ†áÂáÜÈÄªËæëÁé∞Âú®ÈÄÇÁî®„ÄÇËøôÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ÈíàÂØπÊ≠£Â∏∏ÊúüÈó¥ÂÖ≥Èó≠Âπ∂‰∏îÊÇ®ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÁâπÊÆäÊúüÈó¥ÔºåÂàôÂú®‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ÁöÑÊúÄÂêé‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúüÈó¥‰∏≠ËæìÂÖ•Êó•Êúü‰Ωú‰∏∫Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÁöÑËøáË¥¶Êó•Êúü„ÄÇ
Á§∫‰æã
‰ΩøÁî® K4 ‰Ωú‰∏∫‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ÂèòÂºèÔºåÂç≥‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶‰∏éÊó•ÂéÜÂπ¥Áõ∏ÂØπÂ∫îÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÊÇ®ÊúâÂõõ‰∏™ÁâπÊÆäÊúüÈó¥„ÄÇ
‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ YYYY ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊ≠£Â∏∏ÊúüÈó¥Ôºà1ÊúàÂà∞12ÊúàÔºâÂ∑≤ÂÖ≥Èó≠„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåÊÇ®ÊÉ≥Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®ËøáË¥¶ËµÑ‰∫ßÈáç‰º∞Â∫îÁî® (F7775) Âú®Ê≠§‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶‰∏≠ËøõË°åÈáç‰º∞ËøáË¥¶„ÄÇ
ÁÑ∂ÂêéÔºåÊåáÂÆö‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ YYYY ÁöÑ 12 Êúà‰Ωú‰∏∫ËøáË¥¶Êó•Êúü„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂêéÔºåÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂ∞ÜËøáË¥¶Âà∞Ê≠§ËøáË¥¶Êó•ÊúüÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊâìÂºÄÁöÑÊú™Ê∏ÖÁâπÊÆäÊúüÈó¥„ÄÇ
ÂØπ‰∫éÂêàÂêåÂíåÁßüËµÅÁÆ°ÁêÜÔºåËøôÂêåÊ†∑ÈÄÇÁî®‰∫éÂèØÁî®‰∫éËøáË¥¶Âà∞ËµÑ‰∫ßÊàñÂÜ≤ÈîÄËµÑ‰∫ßËøáË¥¶ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ

3. Âü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÁªìÁÆóÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÂíåÂú®Âª∫Â∑•Á®ã
‰πãÂâçÔºåÂè™Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈÄâÈ°πÂèØÁî®‰∫éÈÄöËøáÂú®Âª∫ËµÑ‰∫ß (AuC) Â∞ÜÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÁªìÁÆóÂà∞Â∑≤ÂÆåÊàêËµÑ‰∫ß„ÄÇÂÖàÂâçÁöÑÈÄâÈ°πÂåÖÊã¨‰ªéÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÂà∞Âú®Âª∫Â∑•Á®ãÁöÑÂÆöÊúüÁªìÁÆóÔºõËøô‰∫õÂÆöÊúüÁªìÁÆó‰ª•Ê±áÊÄªÂΩ¢ÂºèËøõË°å„ÄÇ
Áé∞Âú®ËøòÊúâÂè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈÄâÈ°πÔºöÂü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÁªìÁÆó„ÄÇÂØπ‰∫éÂü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÁªìÁÆóÔºå‰∏ç‰ºöÂÆöÊúüÁªìÁÆóÂà∞Âú®Âª∫ËµÑ‰∫ßÔºõÁõ∏ÂèçÔºåÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑÊâÄÊúâËøáË¥¶ÈÉΩ‰ºöÁõ¥Êé•ÂÆåÂÖ®ËøáË¥¶Âà∞Âú®Âª∫ËµÑ‰∫ß„ÄÇÁî±‰∫éÂü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÁªìÁÆóÂ∞ÜÊØè‰∏™Ë°åÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑË°åÈ°πÁõÆÁªìÁÆóÂà∞Âú®Âª∫Â∑•Á®ãÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§Á®çÂêéËØ¶ÁªÜËøáË¥¶‰ªçÊòæÁ§∫Âú®Âú®Âª∫ËµÑ‰∫ß‰∏≠„ÄÇÂü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÁªìÁÆóÈÄÇÁî®‰∫éÂèëÁ•®ÂæÄÂæÄÂæàÂ∞ëÁöÑÁÆÄÂçïÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆ.

ËØ¶ÁªÜÂÜÖÂÆπËØ∑ÂèÇËßÅSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 ‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûª - Âü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁªìÁÆóÁöÑÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÂíåÂú®Âª∫Â∑•Á®ã

4. AppËµÑ‰∫ß‰∏öÂä°ÁöÑËßÜÂõæ‚ÄòÁªìÁÆóÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïË∑üË∏™‚ÄôÊîØÊåÅÂü∫‰∫é‰Ωú‰∏öÁöÑÁªìÁÆó
Âú®ËµÑ‰∫ß‰∫§ÊòìÂ∫îÁî® (F1614) ‰∏≠ÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®ËßÜÂõæ‚ÄòÁªìÁÆóÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïË∑üË∏™‚Äô„ÄÇËØ•ËßÜÂõæÂèØÁî®‰∫éË∑üË∏™Êó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÈìæÔºåËØ•Èìæ‰ªéÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÁªìÁÆóÂºÄÂßãÔºåÂà∞Â∑≤ÂÆåÊàêËµÑ‰∫ßÁöÑËøáË¥¶ÁªìÊùü„ÄÇ
ËØ•ËßÜÂõæÁé∞Âú®ËøòÊèê‰æõÊù•Ëá™Âü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÁªìÁÆóÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåÂç≥ÊúâÂÖ≥Ê∂âÂèäÁöÑÁªÑÁªáÂçï‰ΩçÂíåÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÈìæÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºöÂØπ‰∫éÁâπÂÆöËµÑ‰∫ßÔºåÁªìÁÆó‰∫§Êòì‰∏éÂêà‰Ωú‰ºô‰º¥ËµÑ‰∫ßÔºàÂç≥Âú®Âª∫ËµÑ‰∫ß (AuC)ÔºâÂíåÊäïËµÑÈ°πÁõÆÔºàWBS Ë¶ÅÁ¥†Ôºâ‰∏ÄËµ∑ÂàóÂá∫„ÄÇÊèê‰æõÁªìÁÆóÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂíåÂÖàÂâçÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÁöÑÈìæÊé•ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÂåÖÂê´Âà∞ WBS Ë¶ÅÁ¥†ÁöÑÊàêÊú¨ËøáË¥¶Âíå‰ªé WBS Ë¶ÅÁ¥†Âà∞ AuC ÁöÑÁªìÁÆóËøáË¥¶„ÄÇ

Áî®Êà∑ÁïåÈù¢Á§∫‰æã

5. CDS ËßÜÂõæI_FixedAssetCountryDataÁöÑÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûã
CDS ËßÜÂõæ I_FixedAssetCountryData Êèê‰æõÂØπÂõ∫ÂÆöËµÑ‰∫ßÁöÑÂõΩÂÆ∂/Âú∞Âå∫ÁâπÂÆö‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇ‰πãÂâçÔºåÊÉ≥Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§ËßÜÂõæÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÂøÖÈ°ªÂÖ∑ÊúâÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûã‰∏∫ BURKSÔºàÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÔºâÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤„ÄÇ‰ªé SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 ÂºÄÂßãÔºåËÆ°ÂàíÊ∑ªÂä†‰ª•‰∏ãÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûãÔºö
A_S_MDÔºàÊñ∞ËµÑ‰∫ß‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆÁª¥Êä§ÔºâÔºöÈôêÂà∂ÂØπÊñ∞ËµÑ‰∫ß‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑËÆøÈóÆÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÁî®‰∫é‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆÁª¥Êä§„ÄÇ
BURKS_KOSTLÔºàÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å/ÊàêÊú¨‰∏≠ÂøÉÔºâÔºöÈôêÂà∂ÂØπÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÂíåÊàêÊú¨‰∏≠ÂøÉÁöÑËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇ
BUKRS_WERKSÔºàÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å/Â∑•ÂéÇÔºâÔºöÈôêÂà∂ÂØπÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÂíåÂ∑•ÂéÇÁöÑËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇ
Ë¶ÅÁªßÁª≠Âú®ÊÇ®ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®ËØ• CDS ËßÜÂõæÔºåÊÇ®ÂøÖÈ°ªÂú®ÁâàÊú¨ÂçáÁ∫ßÂà∞ SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 ‰πãÂâçÂ∞ÜÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûãÊ∑ªÂä†Âà∞‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤ÂàÜÈÖçÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï„ÄÇ

6. ÂØπ‰∫éÂ§ñÈÉ®ÂÆ°ËÆ°ÂëòÔºöËµÑ‰∫ß‰ºöËÆ°‰∏≠ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ËåÉÂõ¥ÈôêÂà∂

‚Ä¢ ÁîµÂ≠êË°®Ê†º‰∏äËΩΩ

entry.title: Re: Bulk upload - absence HCP
entry.content:
As implied by Sikindar, it is possible to "Bulk Upload" Absences, with a Start Date and an End Date.

To my knowledge, it is not possible to modify them "in bulk" other than possibly delimit them all on a set date.  Have you tried to create a script with t-code LSMW to delimit them ?

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud: Delete/deactivate depreciation area...
entry.content:
Hello @kingofthe_ring ,

No, you generally cannot delete standard depreciation areas in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 once they are part of a Chart of Depreciation, especially if they are system-delivered.

Try 2 different options as workaround:-

1. Deactivate at the Asset Class Level (Essential Step):
-For every Asset Class your customer uses (or plans to use), go into the "Specify Chart of Depreciation for Asset Class" configuration.
-For Depreciation Area 01 (Book Depreciation) and your chosen Tax Depreciation Area (e.g., 03 or 10), ensure they are active and configured for posting to G/L.
-For all other depreciation areas (e.g., 02, 04, 05, etc.), set them as deactivated for that specific asset class. This prevents values from being calculated or posted in these areas for any new assets created under that class.
-Important: If any assets already exist, even sample ones, ensure their values are zeroed out in the unwanted areas, or consider a data migration strategy if they had actual postings.

2. Verify G/L Account Determination (AO90 / Manage G/L Account Determination for Fixed Assets):
-For the depreciation areas you don't want to use, ensure that no G/L accounts are assigned in the Account Determination for your asset classes. While deactivation at the asset class level should prevent postings, having empty assignments provides an extra layer of safety and indicates that these areas are not meant for financial integration.
-For your desired areas (Book and Tax), ensure all necessary G/L accounts are correctly assigned.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Regarding SAP Signavio Certification
entry.content:
Hello Team,

I am SAP MM certified consultant. I am functional consultant and would like to explore SAP Signavio for career growth. I can see there are 2 certifications available right now for SAP Signavio.  My query is

1. Being a functional SAP MM consultant, which certification among 2 below will be more relevant for me?

2. If there is no straight forward answer to query 1 above then for which type of consultants, certification 1 will be more relevant and for which type of consultants, certification 2 will be more relevant.

SAP Certified Associate - Process Data Analyst - SAP Signavio - C_SIGDA

SAP Certified Associate - Process Management Consultant - SAP Signavio - C_SIGPM

Regards,

Shirin Gupta

entry.title: Re: ML81N IDoc
entry.content:
There is no standard IDoc for ML81N. Some options are there to meet your requirement and they are

 

  1. Define a custom IDoc structure in we30, create a Message Type in we81, map it to the IDoc in we82 and implement the logic via we57.
  2. You can consider BAPI_ENTRYSHEET_CREATE or BAPI_ENTRYSHEET_CREATEFROMDATA to create service entry sheets programmatically.
  3. You could enhance the ML81N transaction using user exits or BAdIs (e.g., BADI_SRV_ENTRY) to trigger outbound communication when a service entry sheet is saved.

entry.title: Re: Delete data from previous months after adding those t...
entry.content:
Hi @Ganjos , 

In 2 nd step you can mention 

DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(11, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(10, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(9, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(8, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(7, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(6, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(5, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(4, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(3, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(2, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0
DATA([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) = 0

 

Or you can direct use delete function:

MEMBERSET [d/CP_DI_Origem] = ("Compromissos")

[d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) 

Delete()

Thanks.

entry.title: Packspec Variations for the same material
entry.content:
We have a business scenario where:

  • Material A is procured from both Vendor A and Vendor B simultaneously.

  • Vendor A supplies Material A in one pack specification (e.g., 1 carton = 15 pieces), while Vendor B supplies the same material in a different pack specification (e.g., 1 carton = 25 pieces).

A straightforward solution would be to standardize the pack specification or split the SKUs and create alternate BOMs. However, this raises two further questions:

  1. If we split Material A into A1 and A2 and assign them to two BOMs using alternate BOMs, how will the system determine which BOM to use? Currently, both Vendor A and Vendor B supply the same material simultaneously.

  2. How will the planning team plan for this SKU? At the moment, they only need to manage a single SKU.

entry.title: Login Methods - PWD, SSO
entry.content:
I am trying to determine how the Login Methods have been assigned to employees within our organisation. 

We appear to have some employees with SSO as their Login Method, some employees with PWD as their Login Method and some employees who appear to have no Login Method at all (which I understand to be the same as SSO).  It's not clear how the Login Method gets populated for an employee in SuccessFactors during the hiring/rehiring process and why some employees appear to have been created with a Login Method of SSO, whilst others have been created with a Login Method of PWD or even no Login Method at all.  How does the system actually determine which Login Method is to be used?  We don't have an Administrator setting these Login Method for individual employees during the hiring process, so the system must be determining the Login Method itself somehow.

Here's what I see in our PRODUCTION system:

  • Those employees who are assigned PWD as their Login Method seem to be either external users OR Onboardees.   We only have 6 countries set up for Onboarding at the moment. 
     
  • Those employees that have no Login Method (Login Method = null) seem to be employees that have been hired from one of the countries that is not use Onboarding.

We asked one employee who has PWD as their Login Method to sign in to SuccessFactors.  Apparently, he was able to do that without receiving any password prompt.   So, even though he has got PWD as the Login Method, he appears to be authenticating via SSO because no password was requested during the sign-on process!   How can this be?

Can anyone please clarify for me how the Login Method gets determined and populated for new employees and rehires.  Am not sure if we have Partial SSO enabled for our organisation but would assume so if we have some employees on SSO and others on PWD?

Regards

entry.title: Re: small batch trial production
entry.content:
You can consider the below options

  • Create multiple production versions for the same material; One for trial production with procurement type E (in-house) and One for formal production with procurement type E50 (phantom). Use production version selection in BOM/routing or via MRP to control which version is used.
  • Define special procurement types in customizing (OMD9) to control behavior like E50 is typically used for phantom assemblies‚Äîno stock, no planned orders. You can create a custom special procurement key that behaves like E but is only used during trial runs.
  • Implement logic in MRP user exits like EXIT_SAPLM61R_001, to dynamically adjust procurement type based on context (trial vs. formal). This is more advanced but offers full control.

entry.title: What's new: SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning ‚Äì 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to the latest updates on SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP). In this blog post, we will highlight the key enhancements and updates introduced in release 2508. You‚Äôll find detailed information in the sections below. 

Enhancements in the SAPIBP1 Sample Planning Area:

In the latest updates to the SAPIBP1 sample planning area, several enhancements have been introduced.

  • We adjusted the assignment of several key figures to the UPSIDE and DOWNSIDE versions. This adjustment ensures that the input key figures are consistently aligned with their respective versions.
  • During the review and optimization of the SAPIBP1 sample planning area, we decided to remove the planning level CALWKPRODLOCCURR. This change helps ensure that the system remains efficient and focused on relevant planning levels, in line with best modelling practices.
  • To improve data clarity and usability at the planning level QTRPRODLOC, the planning level has been updated to use LOCID and PRDID. 

 

IBP for Demand ‚Äì Demand Planning

With the 2508 release, we are introducing a new planning view for the Planner Workspace for Global Demand Planner in the solution process IBP for Demand ‚Äì Demand Planning (11V). This new planning view can be accessed through the contextual navigation feature. It provides additional information about the level at which the forecast was executed. From this view, you can also open the Statistical Forecast Details side panel. This side panel gives you valuable information about the last forecast run, such as a summary of the parameters, which forecast algorithm was used, and whether there were any outline corrections.

Here are two screenshots demonstrating the recent enhancements. The first screenshot shows the new, detailed planning view.

Global Demand Planner: Detailed View

 The next screenshot shows the side panel being used to gather more information about the forecast algorithm.

Global Demand Planner: Side Panel

 

IBP for inventory ‚Äì inventory budget entitlement

We revised the charts of the analytic stories of the IBP for inventory ‚Äì inventory budget entitlement (7UL) solution process and changed their sorting order. As shown in the screenshot below, this allows for a more effective comparison of the budget allocation charts.

Analytics for inventory budget entitlement

 

Test scripts available as XLS files for SAP Cloud ALM

With this release, we are introducing a new accelerator for test scripts. You can now download test scripts as XLS files from SAP Signavio Process Navigator and upload them directly into your SAP Cloud ALM system. With this latest addition, you can easily add test scripts as test cases to your project in SAP Cloud ALM and document the execution of the solution processes.

Example of a test scrip in SAP Cloud ALM

 

Information on Best Practices content on the new planning area Integrated Business Planning (I_SAPIBP2)

We plan to deliver the initial content for the new planning area, Integrated Business Planning (I_SAPIBP2), with the next IBP release (2511). This release is expected to include various solution processes, such as sample data, planner workspaces, analytic stories, and planning views as mentioned on the roadmap ‚Äî so stay tuned.

Here are some more useful links:

  • SAP Signavio Process Navigator to download all assets of SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning
  • Never heard about SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning ‚Äì check out this short video for more information
  • In case you want to learn more about SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning for Supply Chain I recommend our blog series. The first blog is available here.

Thank you for reading our release highlights blog. Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements in future releases.
